output.conclusion: This course provides a solid foundation in linear algebra, equipping you with the tools and knowledge to tackle more advanced topics in mathematics, computer science, and engineering.
output.introduction: Welcome to Linear Algebra! This course builds upon basic linear algebra concepts and delves into more advanced topics, focusing on both theoretical understanding and practical applications. We will explore vector spaces, linear transformations, eigenvalues, eigenvectors, and more.

chapters.description: Axiomatic definition of a vector space. Examples: Euclidean space, function spaces, polynomial spaces. Subspaces and their properties.
Linear independence, spanning sets, basis, and dimension of vector spaces. Examples and exercises.
Representing vectors in different bases. Change of basis matrices and their applications.
Definition of linear transformations, kernel, and range. Examples of linear transformations.
Representing linear transformations with matrices. Composition of linear transformations and matrix multiplication.
Isomorphisms between vector spaces. Invertible linear transformations and their properties.

chapters.chapterTitle: Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors: Definitions and Computation
chapters.description: Definition of eigenvalues and eigenvectors. Characteristic polynomial and its roots.
Diagonalizable matrices and their properties. Conditions for diagonalizability.
Applications in differential equations, Markov chains, and other areas.

chapters.chapterTitle: Inner Product Spaces: Definition and Examples
chapters.description: Definition of inner product spaces. Examples: Euclidean space, function spaces with integrals.
Orthogonal vectors, orthonormal bases, Gram-Schmidt process.
Orthogonal projections onto subspaces. Applications in least squares problems.
Introduction to the singular value decomposition. Definition and properties.
Steps for computing the SVD of a matrix.
Applications in image compression, data analysis, and recommendation systems.
Introduction to Jordan canonical form. Definition and properties.
Steps for computing the Jordan form of a matrix.
Applications in solving systems of differential equations.
